description: In this project you're going to make a game in which you have to throw snowballs at a target. You'll use the mouse pointer to angle the snowball and the spacebar to choose the snowball's power.
name: snowball_fight

steps.title: Making a snowball
steps.description: Make a snowball to throw around your stage

components.text: Open the **Scratch Starter Project**
Make the snowball point towards the players mouse until they press the space bar using the following code

components.blocks:
when flag clicked
		wait (0.5) secs
		go to x:(-200) y:(-100)
		point in direction (90 v)
		switch costume to [snowball-aim v]
		repeat until <key [space v] pressed?>
			point towards [mouse-pointer v]
		end

components.text: **Click the green flag** - Does your snowball follow the mouse until you press the space bar?

steps.title: Setting the snowball power
steps.description: Allow the player to deicde on how powerful the snowball should be thrown

components.text: Create a new variable called `power`
Right-click (or hold Shift and left-click) on the variable display and click `slider`
Drag the variable display to the bottom of the stage, near the snowball
Add this line to your existing code to set your new `power` variable to 0 when the flag is clicked
Use the following script to **set the power of the snowball** *after the direction has been chosen*

components.blocks:
repeat until < not <key [space v] pressed?> >
			change [power v] by (1)
			wait (0.1) secs
		end

components.text: This code means that you have to **keep the space bar held down** after choosing the direction, to choose the snowball's power
**Click the green flag** - Can you choose the snowball angle and power?

steps.title: Throwing the snowball
steps.description: Allow the player to throw the snowball once its direction and power are selected

components.text: Add the following code to the end of your snowball script to broadcast that you're throwing a snowball
Add the following script to your snowball, to move until it reaches the edge of the stage

components.blocks:
when I receive [throw v]
		switch costume to [snowball v]
		repeat until < touching [edge v]? >
			move (power) steps
		end
		hide

components.text: Add this block to the begining of your snowball script to `show` the snowball
**Click the green flag** - Can you make your snowball move at different angles and different speeds?

steps.title: Realistic movement
steps.description: You now have a snowball, but let's make it move a bit more realistically.

components.text: Change your snowball code to look like the following, so that the snowball can't be thrown with a power greater than 20

components.blocks:
repeat until< not <key [space v] pressed?> >
			if < (power) < [20] > then
				change [power v] by (1)
				wait (0.1) secs
			end
		end

components.text: Test out your snowball again, and you'll see that the power never gets above 20.
Right-click on your power variable, and click 'set slider min and max' to **set the maximum value for the variable's slider**
You can also slow down the snowball, by reducing the power slightly as it flies through the air. Add this code block to your snowball's `when I receive [throw]` code:

components.blocks:
if < (power) > (0) > then
			change [power v] by (-0.25)
		end
components.text:
Test this new code - does it work as you expected? You may notice that the power keeps reducing, and eventually the snowball moves backwards!

	To fix this, you can add an `if` block to your code, so that the power is only lowered if it is above 0:

components.blocks:
when I receive [throw v]
		repeat until <touching [edge v]?>
			change y by (-5)
		end
components.text: You're nearly there, but you also need to add some gravity to your snowball, so that it falls to the ground. You can add gravity by just moving the snowball down continuously with this script:
Test out your snowball again, and you should see that your snowball moves much more realistically.

steps.title: The target
steps.description: Let's add in a target for your snowballs!

components.text: + Add in another sprite to your project.

components.blocks:
when flag clicked
		forever
			if < touching [snowball v]? > then
				say [You got me!] for (1) secs
			end
		end
components.text: Add this code to your new sprite, so that it says "You got me!" when it gets hit:
Test out your new code.

Let's do a couple of things to make the game harder. First, let's move the bear each time the player throws the snowball.

	To do this, first add a `broadcast` loop. This will let your bear know that a new shot is about to be taken.

components.blocks:
when I receive [new shot v]
		set x to (pick random (0) to (200))
components.text: When your bear receives this message, move it to a new random position with this code:
Test your project by throwing a few snowballs. Does your bear move position each time?
You can also make your game harder by adding a rock in front of your snowball.
You can now change your snowball code, to stop when it touches the edge of the screen _or_ when it touches the rock. Here's how your snowball code should look:
Finally, you can make your game harder by making your snowball and your bear smaller.
